Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk libseccomp
exit 0

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: libseccomp bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: The libseccomp library provides an easy to use interface to the Linux kernel's syscall filtering mechanism, seccomp. The libseccomp API allows an application to specify which syscalls, and optionally which syscall arguments, the application is allowed to execute. Both the syscalls and the syscall arguments are enforced by the Linux kernel. This update fixes the following bugs: Previously, the libseccomp packages listed the kernel package as a dependency. This dependency caused problems in container environments where libseccomp was installed, because libseccomp packages downloaded the kernel package as well as other packages, unnecessarily supporting packages. With this update, libseccomp no longer lists the kernel as a dependency. (BZ#1066136) The libseccomp packages' manual pages used the term "process" in many places where there should be "thread". These updated packages contain the corrected manual pages. (BZ#1177724) Additionally, this update adds the following enhancement: The libseccomp packages now support the 64-bit ARM architecture. (BZ#1066136) Users of libseccomp are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add this enhancement. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
